A schoolboy has been airlifted to hospital after being hit by a 40ft falling tree on his way to school. 
The teenager was walking to school on Nell Lane in the Chorlton area of Manchester when he was struck by the tree at around 8.50am this morning. 
The boy was airlifted to Manchester Royal Infirmary after suffering injuries to his arms and legs. 
The Manchester Evening News reports the boy - believed to be aged 14 or 15 - was not seriously injured. Read More Disabled man splashes £7,000 inheritance and benefits on 'addiction' to prostitutes to relieve his symptoms The boy was airlifted to Manchester Royal Infirmary 
A Greater Manchester Police spokesman said: "The boy had a very lucky escape. It was a very large tree. It missed the rest of his body by just inches. He could have been very seriously hurt. 
“The air ambulance landed nearby and took him to the MRI as a precaution. He had bruises to one of his legs and some scratches.” 
The tree, described as at least three storeys tall, blocked Nell Lane until emergency services were able to clear the fallen debris. Read More Corrie McKeague: Missing RAF airman's mum fears body in landfill tip and slams police for not searching site sooner 
Traffic was being diverted through a nearby cemetery while tree surgeons removed the tree from the road. 
Eye-witness Michael Shaw, 47, who lives nearby, said: “The tree had fallen across the road. It had completely obstructed the road to all traffic. Everyone was having to turn back and find a different way around. 
“I saw a boy being helped to walk by some other school kids. He was limping but he looked okay.” Like us on Facebook
